metadata.title: Self-Employment Tax Calculator (Detailed & Quick Estimates)
metadata.description: Estimate self-employment (SE) tax, employer-equivalent deduction, and a simple federal income tax estimate. Two modes: a detailed split (Social Security, Medicare, Additional Medicare) and a quick rule-of-thumb estimate. Includes quarterly payment suggestion and accuracy notes.

detailed.label: Detailed estimate (recommended)
detailed.description: Calculates net earnings at 92.35% of profit, splits Social Security and Medicare, applies an optional Social Security wage base cap, and applies Additional Medicare Tax thresholds by filing status.

ss_taxable.expression: ss_wage_base > 0 ? min(net_earnings, max(0, ss_wage_base - social_security_wages_other)) : net_earnings
ss_taxable.label: Social Security taxable portion of net earnings (after other wages)

social_security_tax.label: Social Security portion of SE tax (12.4%)

additional_medicare_threshold.label: Additional Medicare Tax threshold by filing status

employer_equivalent_deduction.label: Deductible employer-equivalent portion (half of SE tax)

taxable_income_estimate.label: Estimated taxable income after SE deduction (simple estimate)

estimated_income_tax.label: Estimated federal income tax owed (simple rate-based estimate)

total_tax.label: Estimated total tax liability (SE tax + income tax)

quarterly_payment.label: Suggested estimated quarterly payment (if no other credits)

quick.label: Quick estimate (single-rate rule)
quick.description: Rule-of-thumb: apply a combined 15.3% SE tax rate to 92.35% of profit and a simple income-tax estimate using an input tax rate.

introduction: This calculator estimates self-employment tax (Social Security and Medicare) and provides a simple federal income tax estimate and suggested quarterly payment. It supports a detailed split of taxes and a quick rule-of-thumb mode.

Results are estimates only. Use the detailed mode for closer alignment with IRS-defined components (net earnings, Social Security wage base, Additional Medicare Tax thresholds). Do not consider this a substitute for professional tax advice.
methodology: Net earnings from self-employment are computed as 92.35% of net profit (gross receipts minus allowable business expenses) to reflect the IRS calculation for self-employment tax.

Self-employment tax is split into Social Security (12.4% on the applicable wage base) and Medicare (2.9% on net earnings). Additional Medicare Tax (0.9%) is applied on earnings above filing-status thresholds. The calculator optionally applies a Social Security wage base if provided.

Income tax is estimated by applying a user-provided effective federal tax rate to a simplified taxable income estimate (other taxable income plus net profit minus the deductible half of SE tax). This is a simplified approach for planning and is not a substitute for a full tax return calculation.
how_is_calculated: Social Security taxable portion = if a wage base is provided: min(net earnings, wage base − other Social Security wages) else net earnings
Social Security tax = Social Security taxable portion × 12.4%
Additional Medicare = max(0, net earnings − filing-status threshold) × 0.9%
Self-employment tax = Social Security tax + Medicare tax + Additional Medicare
Estimated income tax = max(0, (other taxable income + (net profit − employer-equivalent deduction)) × effective tax rate − withheld tax)
Total tax = self-employment tax + estimated income tax; quarterly payment = total tax ÷ 4
examples: Example (detailed): Gross income $80,000; expenses $15,000; net earnings = ($80,000 − $15,000) × 0.9235 = $60,372. Self-employment tax splits into Social Security, Medicare, and any Additional Medicare as applicable. The employer-equivalent deduction reduces estimated taxable income.
Example (quick): Same profit with 15.3% applied to net earnings gives a fast SE tax estimate without wage-base capping or Additional Medicare splitting.
summary: Use the detailed mode for closer alignment with IRS calculations. Use the quick mode for a fast planning estimate.

Enter a Social Security wage base to cap the Social Security portion when you know the current year wage base. Leave it zero to ignore the cap (useful for partial-year planning or when other wages are not known).

faqs.question: Is this an exact tax return calculation?
faqs.answer: No. This tool produces planning estimates only and does not replace a tax return, professional advice, or software that computes tax with full schedules and credits.

faqs.question: Where do the rates come from?
faqs.answer: The calculator uses common statutory SE tax rates (12.4% Social Security, 2.9% Medicare, plus 0.9% Additional Medicare above thresholds). Wage bases and exact thresholds change yearly; enter a wage base value if you want the cap applied.

faqs.question: Why do you use 92.35% of net profit?
faqs.answer: The IRS prescribes that net earnings subject to self-employment tax are generally 92.35% of net profit to account for the employer-equivalent portion that self-employed people effectively pay.

faqs.question: Is this tool secure and reliable?
faqs.answer: We follow recognized security and testing practices (see citations) for data handling. Accuracy depends on user inputs and assumptions; always verify with official IRS guidance or a tax professional.

glossary.definition: Profit from self-employment multiplied by 92.35%, the IRS basis for calculating self-employment tax.
Combined Social Security and Medicare tax for self-employed individuals; includes an Additional Medicare component above income thresholds.
Half of the self-employment tax that is deductible when computing income tax.
An extra 0.9% Medicare tax on earnings above filing-status thresholds (applies to higher-income taxpayers).
Maximum earnings subject to Social Security tax in a calendar year; changes annually per IRS guidance. Enter 0 to ignore wage-base capping in this tool.
